pros: - Full Time - Benefits - Good experience doing community work - Helps kids
cons: - Layoffs - Doesn't care for your health - Dishonesty - Feel not valued

job_title: Community Wellness Specialist in Pasadena, CA
pros: Flexibility in work hours, empathetic staff, mediocre pay, and you will gain lots of experience working with with consumers that are transferable.
cons: Can be high stress, and some consumers can be high risk. They do not use buddy system for field engagement, and one on one work. This can put you into sketchy situations that are unsafe. You must be your own advocate regarding this because many are pushed even if uncomfortable with the work environment.

job_title: Community Wellness Specialist in Pasadena, CA
pros: gain experience, supportive staff, great co workers, helping clients who actually want it good agency that helps people
cons: Low pay with High stress, Billing productivity quotas, can’t take pto unless you meet your billing productivity but mangers can take all the pto they want. High risk clients that don’t want help

pros: Some managers are great and easy to work with
cons: Expectations are unrealistic in regards to productivity

job_title: Youth Specialist I in Altadena, CA
pros: Real-time, face to face experience with clients that struggle with mental health disorders, trauma, substance abuse, etc. This is great for anyone interested in pursuing a career in social work, mental health, and positions in law enforcement (e.g. probation officer). Good OT and decent benefits for full-time employees.
cons: This company advertises itself as a therapeutic haven for minors in the foster care system, but many of the kids here suffer bullying and abuse at the hands of other minors with more severe behavioral issues than them. As staff, you are often overworked, stressed, etc. and placed in dangerous situations due to constant understaffing, lack of effective safety measures, and ongoing verbal and physical fights in the premises. There are few concrete consequences for punishing bad behavior, so clients find ways to override the rules and undermine authority. There are staff that have been there for years and very obviously have stopped caring about the kids' safety/treatment, and often turn to the use of bribes to elicit desired behavior.

review_title: Good place to get your hours and trainings

cons:

People get burnt out quickly 
Too many programs
The pay for therapist was low and you have to use your car 
You are on call for 1 week but not too often

review_title: Company That Tries to Give Back to Employees
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
A lot of the upper level staff are very considerate and assist with managing productivity. 
Opportunities and support for career growth/upward mobility.
Opportunities to earn CEU's .
Opportunities for certification with various evidence based treatment modalities.
Upper management genuinely tries to find rewards, bonuses, and opportunities that feel satisfying for staff.
Transparency regarding productivity and how your productivity contributes to the finances of the business.
cons:
Working for any DMH contracted company means that there are very high expectations for quality of services with protocols that can change rapidly.
Productivity is under constant monitor and it can be challenging to complete all notes and intakes within the allotted time.

pros: Great place to work and everyone is super nice!
cons: There are no cons to working as everyone is nice!

review_title: Everyday is new and be prepared to be strong
job_title: Youth Specialist I in Altadena, CA
pros: There’s always work. Build lots of experience on the job because you have to work with kids and teenagers in various ages and disorders and behaviors. You have to be a mentor, clinician, teacher, drill sergeant in this position and you’ll know when to be either one when situations arise that occur often and different approaches and solutions in crisis situations or normal unnecessarily situations form emotionally disturbed youths. Can ready you for any job in the future and my confidence had increased in levels I didn’t think I can. This is not your normal job, your patience, self esteem , respect, dignity will be tested and be on the line and you have to be composed and figure how to resolve conflict.
cons: It’s mentally draining and overtime seems to be every week. No social life or very little. On my day off or two of that I want to rest or read. Hardly turn up but I guess that is a luxury form what I’m learning.

pros: Great people and staff. The clients are so fun to work with
cons: Lots of driving, the paperwork is insane, if you're single and ready to throw yourself into work, this is the place for you

pros: Great leadership, I great benefits
cons: Pay is not great ok.

job_title: Clinician I in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Heavy Documentation. Field based with some long commutes.

pros:

review_title: No work-life balance whatsoever & becoming a hostile work environment
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Pasadena, CA
pros:
Hours towards licensure
Flexibility
Make your own schedule
cons:
No work-life balance.
Management claims they care but don’t support you in the end.
Can be dangerous especially field based.
You are on call 24/7. Clients WILL call you on weekends.
For the TILP program you are expected to unlock client’s apartment doors if they lock themselves out. This applies on weekdays, weeknights, weekends, and holidays.

pros:
1. Paid time off is pretty generous after a few years working for the company 
2. many training opportunities to get certified for evidence based practices 
3. Hardworking coworkers who really care about helping people and underserved youth 
4. 40 hours of paid study time for clinicians 
5. Some supervisors are very supportive 
6. flexible schedule
cons:
1. expect to take home work with you most days, for DMH contracted agencies, the paperwork can be very overwhelming!!  

2. you can be consistent with productivity but there will be burnout, high compassion fatigue 

3. there’s a lot of meetings and planning but not enough action from management at times 

4. not the best electronic health record, the department is always backed up with 1-2 people 
overwhelmed with the many hats they wear

5. clinicians don’t always stay too long once they find another opportunities that pay well, better benefits, with less stressful workload 

6. paperwork and updates in the programs are ALWAYS changing, expect to keep up with these many changes 

7. there is a disconnect with the upper management ELT to the other sites, they visit and have these tours or meetings to explain their roles, policies etc. .......but you don’t see them again for another 8 months to a year.

pros: Many shifts available. Flexible schedule.
cons: The Program structure is lacking

job_title: Youth Specialist I in Pasadena, CA
pros: Interaction with clients and co-workers.
cons: They don't care about their employees' safety and the pay is atrocious.

review_title: Working here allows you to make a difference for children and families!
pros: Flexible schedule, room for growth, competitive pay,  great benefits, team-based approach to providing best practice mental health services, lots of training opportunity, innovation, exposure to the systems that surround us with opportunities to sit at the table and have a voice (DMH, DCFS, Probation, ACHSA and state level advocacy).  Here, you get to work with the most vulnerable youth and families and support them in recovering from trauma and other mental health challenges.  There is great supervisors and managers to provide training, support, and consultation.
cons: Lots of paperwork (that's DMH's doing, not HSCFS), as a contract provider we have to follow there guidelines.  Also, it would be great if the operations departments could be decentralized to have more integration with the programs they support.  Also, always room to grow with technology!

review_title: Good Experience. Needs work as does any company.
pros:
I was not micro-managed. Can't say the same for my co-worker.
PTO
Small Team
Paid training
Free coffee
Left overs from meetings
Doughnuts from a nice co-worker
Nice Staff
cons:
Traffic even though I was less than 20 miles away. Both ways!
Person managing me knew less than they should. Always went to the team for answers
Review process was poor
Non-profit so prepare to be offered low pay even with years of experience.
Since everything is on a budget it is hard to get the technology you need to get your job done.
A lot of talk but not a lot of walk

review_title: My experience has been full of challenging work. It stays busy and I enjoy working  with my families
pros: Great to work with the families and helping them stay together, or get back together and being resourceful. It brings great joy to see families learning how to grow together by putting in place and practing the steps to help them succeed in life. It is a wonderful feeling to know that you have made a difference
cons: Nonprofit-So trying to get an increase in pay is not always  easy. I understand every company has a budget and must have a strategic plan when it comes to pay raises, but since we deal with the county, although we are not a county contracted job, it has an impact on our money.

pros: Great clinical training, good benefits, generous PTO
cons: Very top-heavy leadership, inconsistent management positions across departments, members of senior leadership make insensitive generalized remarks about clients , over-emphasis of how we appear to others  and not enough emphasis on quality of care, As long as our results appear to look good to others (regardless if they are true representations), leadership is happy. No one at the top seems to care about actual client care.

pros: Competative benefits package; flexible schedule
cons:
Once you're considered on the management radar your work life can be a nightmare. Their mission statement does not carry over onto employee satisfaction. If you speak up about things being unfair, you are pushed out of the company. The executive leadership team is more concerned about the awards they can add to their resume's than employee satisfaction. They pretend to care, but strip people of their dignity and happiness. They proclaim to be supportive of "self-care" and do not create an environment in which to gain any.
Almost every therapist is forced to work after hours and on the weekends because there is not enough time in the day to complete the work they require. There is not enough support for the amount of work-load. Compensation is excessively below industry standards.
The only way to be promoted is if you're "liked" or know someone who can put in a good word.

review_title: Hathaway-Sycamores offers many excellent MHS services to children, families and TAY youth.
pros: Clinical supervisors are good to excellent. Multiple locations in LA County. Good benefits. Salaries are average. Some very good to excellent upper management. Lots of opportunities to learn how to work with clients who are very challenging. Colleagues are wonderful and supportive. Supportive and helpful Quality Management. Great team players in charts and records department. Focus on the family as a whole, not just identified client.
cons: They are going through some upper management changes that can feel confusing to employees in the satellite offices. Salaries could be more competitive. Communication throughout the agency and between different satellite offices can be challenging.

pros:
Flexible work schedule
Great benefits 
Nice PTO options
You'll find pockets of really good, amazing people.
cons: This is a highly structured organization with many many layers of leadership and authority. It's a rather large agency - around 600-650 people at any given time. With such a large number of staff, the layers of leadership make it feel clunky and mismanaged. The highest level of organization should be more concerned with their visibility amongst their staff and make more effort to get to know line staff or even the operations staff at their office.

review_title: Chaos, Favoritism and Drinking the Kool-aid
pros: Coworkers, benefits, helping families and children.
cons: Where to start...This is the type of agency that in one hand needs to save money by cutting whole departments while at the same time decides to promote the CEOs buddies to new levels. Apparently there is a need to have sites with a Vice-President 2, a Vice-President 1, AVP, Director, Assistant Directors and supervisors.  What these people do all day is a mystery.  I imagine they spend their day telling each other how innovative they are and agreeing with the latest half-baked idea from ELT.  A place where the technology is at least 5 years behind (hello Windows 7) and saves money by providing new phones with 3G technology. The laptops are a relic from 7 years ago. Forget having a tablet or a working hot spot. An agency that thinks that therapist’s time should be spent doing data entry, making photocopies, and dealing with the worst Electronic Health Record known to man.  An agency that decides to do an open floor plan for all their new buildings but has no space for sessions or for staff to work quietly. Where decisions, such as centralizing all the agency’s referral teams, tripling the amount of residential beds, going into Adult Mental Health or eliminating the whole IT department are done haphazardly, with little or no planning and no consultation from the staff that is actually doing the job. Working here feels like a rollercoaster managed by the whims of a toddler.  Just when you think that things are stable, ELT comes up with a new way to create chaos  in the name of innovation. There is a strong culture of favoritism, particularly for males.  There is a lot of talk about accountability, but that is only true of some line staff. Senior management never take responsibility for errors or mismanagement and there is an expectation for all personnel not to question or complain the bad decisions made.  An agency that wants you to pretend you are part of an innovative, forward looking organization while you are working in a bloated dinosaur run by people interested in maintaining their salaries and status. There is no integrity or regard to the hard work done by line staff everyday. I hope the Board wakes up and changes the leadership.

review_title: Incredible advocates for children and families in need
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I have been a full-time employee for more than a year.  There is a huge sense of pride in the work that is done here.  The needs of the children and families served always come first.  The staff is collaborative at all levels and I feel inspired on a daily basis.  The salary and benefits are also super competitive.  Benefits are great!  The new CEO is very supportive of staff and has a deep understanding of the work being done at the agency on all levels.
cons: I have yet to find any downsides to working here.  Recognition for meeting targeted goals is great!

pros:
Flexible schedule (but trust me, it still doesnt benefit you.)
Generous PTO
Passionate co-workers
cons:
You're making less than minimum wage once you've finished all of the work expected of you. It's not an exaggeration, so don't fall for the "higher pay" delusion. 
Middle management is concerned with not getting written up and will throw you under the bus before they go an inch to help staff. 
Poor organization in almost every department. So many flawed sub-systems produces mediocre work..all at the expense of the staff that actually bill's. 

Just don't work here. Truth is, if you've been here for years, you're underqualified to go elsewhere and like being "comfortable" or are too scared to find happiness or you've so long you don't know another way to collect a paycheck. Either way, you deserve each other.

pros: Great people to work with  (minus management).
cons: The lack of support given by management. Management never acknowledges good work but are quick to point out ones mistakes. Never been in a workplace where the value of an employee means so little and management can turn on an employee. If you're not a manager in this job you're not appreciated whatsoever. Lucky if you are able to get a "hello" from some of the managers or better yet if they even know your name.

pros: very generous PTO, dedicated clinicians
cons: Leadership is corrupt. Ineffective people in management positions at "Headquarters" get promoted way too easily just because they have friends in high places. Meanwhile, hardworking managers get overlooked and treated like dirt. And HR has been a disorganized mess since the day I got here.

pros: Incredible colleagues who care about the population.  They have to pay employees for the work they do rather they want to or not.
cons: If you're the right ethnicity certain liberties are given.  Special positions are created to accommodate some based on who "likes" them rather than on ability.  Leadership lack leadership skills and staff are treated poorly.  Clearly the Board of Directors provide little oversight because they're entangled with the Organization through providing services to the Agency while also serving on the Board; for them it's a sure fire sale or products and services.  Who is safe guarding the mission????

review_title: Over 7 years: would have quit each year if I could have.
pros: MFT Interns don't have many attractive job opportunities, so finding a position with an ok salary and benefits is appealing as one gathers hours towards licensure.
cons:
It's all about the money- and I'm not talking about your $. The reality is that this nonprofit has a one-track mind: have you billed enough this week? 

If the answer is no, that you haven't met their high billing expectations, you will be micromanaged until you do so. If the answer is yes, it's unlikely you've stopped working - it's impossible to keep a decent work-life balance and meet their expectations.

HR and payroll are the most incompetent departments, and that's saying a lot: I have had my paycheck $, time off accrual, and benefits screwed up by them more times than I can count. Each time they have attempted to fix it after I caught their errors (which have been major - most recently, they deleted 1 month of my earned time off from their system. Another time they forgot to give me benefits after I signed up for them. I could go on..). Those poor people who don't check their pay stubs for accuracy!

The outpatient and school-based programs are the most well-run, and the Wraparound program is the least well-run. I can't speak for the group home, but it seems pretty poorly run as well.

I've stayed at Hathaway Sycamores for 7 years because I didn't have viable alternatives (I figured that all DMH jobs would be similar), and I have valued the kids I have served. But, I strongly believe that the billing and paperwork demands on DMH agencies becomes the primary focus of the work, to the detriment of the clients and the morale of the employees.

I also strongly believe that this agency will not change their ways. Despite significant record-lows on the employee satisfaction surveys this year, the executive leadership team has made no positive changes. 

To conclude: if you're looking for a DMH-agency mental health position, you're going to find the same challenges wherever you go (mismanagement, excessive and repetitive paperwork, and an emphasis on billing at the expense of any semblance of self-care). At this large agency, you might find a job that will get you hours towards licensure and benefits. You'll also feel inspired to serve kids who are resilient despite incredible adversity. But you will not be supported, and your quality of life will be very poor, particularly if you are not working in one of the few programs with consistent working hours. 

Wonderful people are drawn to this kind of work, and I enjoyed most of my coworkers immensely. But Hathaway-Sycamores: I can't wait to quit you.

pros: My experience working for HSCFS over the years has been generally positive. Originally, I applied for a position here because of Debbie Manner's reputation as a champion for children and families. She inspired and supported me to further my career and obtain a master degree. I've stayed through all the changes because I believe she is the right type of leader to move the agency forward and advance our mission.
cons: If you don't like continuous changes and challenges...growth and quality improvement then you won't thrive at this agency.

review_title: Good stepping stone. Get your hours and up in rank or out to a better place.
pros: Service to the community is priceless. Some staff that work face to face with community actually care about what they do. The upgrades to certain offices were nice. Community Wellness Specialist (aka Youth Specialist) hourly rate is competitive.  Database is same one that DMH uses.  ELT talks like they care about the families we serve.  Desire to expand. Great job at containing spread of information regarding lawsuits against the agency.
cons:
Agency getting smaller contracts from DMH year after year. It's non-profit BUSINESS, never forget this. 

Productivity focused. Progress notes is the single most important thing of your job. Do your notes and you will be liked by management. Staff often overbill for services to meet productivity. Agency forced staff to sign agreements that they will be subjected to disciplinary action and possible termination if they do not meet productivity. 

Pending lawsuits; wrongful death from former client and employment related suits from former staff.

Lancaster office staff overhaul drama. After the major reorganization of the agency, people were promoted to new positions that should have never been promoted. A lot of really good people left after the re-organization. 

Low morale. Staff often complaining about their jobs. Agency hires outside consultants to make decisions. 

There is no union. You will have to fend for yourself if you ever have complaints against a superior or are subjected to disciplinary action. Tread lightly when it comes to complaints about your job or coworkers. 

Upper management staff are disconnected from the actual service delivery experience. 

Survival of the agency trumps ethical and mandated reporting decisions. You may be asked to do things that go against your professional ethics.   

Clinicians often work overtime with no overtime pay.

review_title: Good salary and benefits but unrealistic expectations.
pros: The training is remarkable. Salary and benefits are good. Most direct supervisors provide needed support. They pay for driving and cellular phone usage. They provide bonuses if you meet billing expectations per week.
cons: Their billable expectations are extremely high so in order to meet them, an employee must work on average 50 hours per week and get paid for 40. Upper management gets very high salaries while the clinicians (who do all the work) get an average income.

review_title: Toxic envirnment at company that has lost its vision to help children
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: As with any job you get a paycheck and benefits, but at what cost? My health is not worth any pros Hathaway-Sycamores has to offer.
cons: There are so many! Management has no sense of direction and rather put out fires rather than find long term feasible solutions.  Everything is a number# and or percentage %....what happened to the human factor???

job_title: Group Home Counselor in Altadena, CA
pros: Love working with teen boys, working with staff as a team member going for the same goals in a pisitive manner.
cons: Staff issues, Black, White, Hispanic all at odds with each other. Write ups on negative staff breaking rules disappearing from files.  Favortism from Supervisors, (What z this teaching the boys?) Pay could be better.

review_title: If you are looking to join management avoid like the plague this is.
pros: Direct care staff are very committed to the work and the mission.  Generous PTO. Some good clinical training and supervision.
cons: This is by far one of the worst agencies I have worked for.  The culture is toxic. There is a real divide between those doing the work and those “directing” the work.   There are unnecessary layers of management that just makes communication so much more difficult than it needs to be.  There is a culture of cronyism and fear. Tips to succeed here:  Be male, be white and/or act white, praise the very weak-egoed, narcissistic CEO at every opportunity, don’t speak up, foster and feed the delusion that the organization is cutting-edge, innovative and all decisions by the Executive Leadership team are inspired and visionary. The last two years had very poor employee satisfaction surveys which enrages and confuses senior management. Instead of figuring out core issues, or have some self-reflection, the senior staff become defensive and completely ignite the issues.  Retention rate among clinicians is atrocious, most leaving after a couple of years. For those interested in a clinical supervisor position: not only are you responsible for supervising 6-8 staff, but the last two years they have forced productivity expectations for this position of 3-5 hours a week to “help” the bottom line.   You will also have to clean up charts, cover and open cases and train  more than in comparable agencies because of the turn-over rate.  You will also be on call and will have to train to be an LPS even if your primary programs are non-intensive.  Your role is that of plantation foreman, not trainer or mentor.   There is also different treatment according to what site you work for, divided by which Senior Vice-President oversees your site. Let’s just say one team has more promotions, better compensation and less punitive measures than the other and better retention among middle management.   You will feel like an expendable cog in a broken machine.

pros:
-Flexible hours
-Great people at all levels and departments of the company
-Management and colleagues are very friendly, understanding, and supportive
-Amazing new CEO that brings great energy to the agency 
-Easy-going work environment
-Chances to work on great, challenging projects
-A lot of room for growth and learning
-Career advancement opportunities
-Great work/life balance
cons: I've been here for a year and my experience has been all positive.

review_title: Punitive Staff, Issues with Racism towards staff, Vindictive and unsupportive management!
pros: They have great refreshments at meetings and during trainings!
cons: Upper level managers can be deceitful and unsupportive. Previous comments about being micromanaged and targeted are absolutely true! Be careful and DO NOT GET ON THEIR RADAR! They will go after you! Mix in race, and you've got another level of reasons that may make you a target. I too have seen great, supportive, and hard-working staff leave this agency because of deceitful and vindictive upper management. I would strongly recommend that no African American clinician apply to work at this agency! Trust me... look elsewhere!

pros: This was my first Accountjng job, and what an awesome opportunity. Coworkers made it all worth it, got the chance to work with some of the most talented/giving people in the non profit industry. I’ve had convos with top management and all of them just want you to succeed.
cons: There are a lot of time crunches on the finance end. But that comes with any job, and isn’t as tight as say public accounting.

pros: Good benefits, great learning experience, meet a lot of helpful and great people working in mental health, work together type environment, helping out, a lots of good programs provided to the consumers.
cons: Company doesn't take care of their employees. Everything is productivity to them and meeting it, pushing you to the limit until you are burn out. Management ( not all) provides poor support and doesn't communicate well.

pros: The best thing about working at Hathaway is definitely the people. I worked at the corporate office in Pasadena and loved it. All of my coworkers were fun and friendly.
cons: Some of the downsides are lack of communication between the execs and the line staff.

pros: They have many locations.
cons: No transparency from executive team. The CEO, Debbie Mammers has ran it to the ground. They don’t care about providing quality services. They want the numbers $$$. They are constantly in crisis when it comes to finances.  Every year they say they’ve run out of money and everyone worries whether they are going to have a job.

pros: The kids and their families. Reimbursement for registration and testing materials. Coworkers are great too.
cons: Micromanaging management. Racial insensitivity. General ignorance and a focus on numbers only.

review_title: Loved my co workers and the families I served. But management was a nightmare.
pros: Experience,  training,  trial by fire, teamwork, PTO, flexibility,  assessment skills
cons: Some very poor and toxic supervisors, double bind communication, passive aggressive management,  egos running the show, micromanagement,  ridiculous expectations,  very unhealthy mental health agency.

pros: Challenging work where you can make a difference in the community.
cons: Lots of driving, hourly work means you end up working off the clock if you want to hit your weekly productivity (illegal), poor work/life balance, mediocre pay.  They talka good game when it comes to self care but the real importance is on hitting your productivity numbers.  Upward mobility is very limited and poor if you are not a clinician.

review_title: Excellent mission, if they could stick to it
pros: Passionate coworkers, talented therapists and staff, dedicated team members, flexibility (working in the comminuty, working form home sometimes), good training and networking opportunities
cons: HUGE gap in communication between management and everyone else. Paperwork is overwhelming. After awhile, paperwork and billing becomes more important than client care.

pros: Great experience with DCFS and Probation youths.
cons: Not a great long term job. Get your experience and do not get comfortable. Lost of favoritism and racism in the residential facilities. Mind your business, do your job and move on.

pros: Staff, PTO, mileage reinbursement
cons:
HR is a ongoing joke here. 
They constantly make careless errors and can’t even answer basic HR questions. 
They never answer calls or emails when you need help. 
Management are a bunch of egocentric people who have no idea of running things. 
If management was so great than why is there such a high turn around rate. Pay is not worth the anxiety, stress, and lack of social life. 
Don’t forget to bill or you’ll be bullied and then fired.

pros: Great management staff. This company allows employees to take time off when needed.  They care about staff
cons: working with children day in and day out can get mentally exhausting.  Mental exhaustion is the only draw back to this Job.

pros: Co-workers, good benefits, help the community. Good training and supervision.
cons: The agency is horribly managed. You don't get even basic supplies like pens, pads or post-it notes.  Bad follow-through from HR.  For some reason there are tons of managers with no clear division of who does what.  The focus is all on billing and numbers. The turnover of staff is ridiculous. You can do the same job at other agencies with less drama.

pros: There really are no Pros to working in the Lancaster office!
cons: The management is a nightmare. The director that's been there for years is fake and mental.. Supervisors are immature and over worked and there is nothing good about this location. There is a reason they offer a sign on bonus and that is because no one will stay. This company gives the bare minimum to their employees. There are so many other companies that offer so much more and you don't have to deal with immature and mental management.

pros: Great co-workers minus management. 11 paid holidays.
cons: Low pay, micromanaged, tons of work and billing is all that matters. Management thinks you have no life and expect you to work 7 days a week. Management have big egos but when there's a crisis have no idea what to do. HR are the most uneducated people you will meet. They have made big mistakes in my paychecks and co- workers. This agency will never be able to keep the good employees.

pros: Great place to gain experience and collect your hours quickly for direct care staff (Clinicians). Co-workers are awesome.
cons: Upward mobility is difficult. Pay is not competitive. Direct care staff are burnt out. Huge systems and management issues.

pros: Flexible work schedule, current technology, great benefits.
cons: Difficult to grow professionally, difficult to be a creative thinker, agency has had many systematic changes in the past 3 years which has resulted in numerous clinical and management turnover and instability.

job_title: Youth Specialist in El Nido, CA
pros: Substantial experience!!!now these days you need a lot of experience to work whether or not you have a degree. I have one with any experience in the field and got hired! Grateful for that. hiring process 3 weeks or less and your good to go!
cons: I am not sure what to put

pros: Great mission. Innovation is encouraged. Set's the example for the rest of the field.
cons: Because Hathaway-Sycamores serves the most challenging population you really have to work to not be affected by vicarious trauma. They do have support for you in this.

pros: The only good thing is good location.
cons: Shady positions that they open for a day and when you want to apply they say the position has been filled, meaning it was created for someone from outside but they didn’t even give the opportunity to qualified staff that are waiting for an opportunity

pros: The organization, staff and management really care about providing quality mental health to youth in need.  There are a lot of growth opportunities...ELT visits my site regularly to let us know of them.
cons: So far I am having a positive experience.

job_title: R B S Facilitator in Altadena, CA
pros: Learned alot about my position and the field of which I was apart of
cons: This is an Agency that is NON-PROFIT,and if you don't reach the numbers they let you know it's about PROFIT

pros: Health benefits and PTO are decent.
cons: Money, money, money and manipulative management. It's all about feeding their ego.

pros: Working and making a difference in lives of children and families.
cons:
Too many VP/AVPs/Directors, Assistant Directors, Assistant to the Assistant Directors, Assistant to the Assistant to the Assistant Director. 

Research  department has 100 staff members, all incredibly over paid. 

Too much focus on profits, for a non-profit

Reorganization of the agency was a total failure

Reorganization and "centralizing of referral team" is a total failure

pros: The management and staff are great . The clients are great
cons: Low pay and high case load. A lot of driving. Not many raises. No holiday bonus. Incentives are not great .

review_title: Great Place to Work Helping Children and Families!
pros: Treatment philosophy is amazing, supportive environment, great training.
cons: Large company that has grown and sometimes lacks communication.

review_title: Doing good deeds, but needs a complete overhaul
pros: The mission is very compelling and the work itself is very rewarding
cons: Leadership is in disarray and doesn't work as a team.

review_title: No room for growth within the agency
pros: Insurance, phone plans discounts, flexible with hours
cons: No room for Growth, lots of favoritisms towards the employees who don’t complete their work and they let go the good hard working  employees.  Very bad low salaries for hard working employees and for upper level they get the good salaries and some don’t even do anything.

pros: Clinical experience, support of colleagues, benefits
cons: Poor management of senior leadership, lack of recognition for work, low morale, low pay

pros: You get good experience working with families
cons: There are too many chiefs and not enough workers.

pros:
Clients
Coworkers (not management)
Training that provides clinical staff with good skills 
Excellent cafeteria at el Nido site
Ability to obtain supervised hours towards licensure
cons:
Abusive insensitive management
Obscenely low pay
Taking away all incentives 
Unrealistic expectations 
Lack of management support in situations with clients and families (regardless of safety issues)

pros: Pay isn't horrible, solid benefits
cons: Staff is cliquey, management is inept, job was misleading

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Pacoima, CA
pros: Great  benefits, flexible schedule, working in a team setting, working with various demographics.
cons: Long paperwork, productivity, detailed initial assessment.

pros: Supportive staff, flexible hours, great benefits
cons: Long days and hard work at times given the nature of the industry

pros: Training is very good and experience is worthwhile.
cons: Upper management does not listen to staff and cares about productivity instead of client care.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Covina, CA
pros: Great colleagues and valuable work with the community and the young.
cons: Productivity,  timeliness, and documentation process outdated.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: professional, ethical, thorough, great people and training opportunities
cons: lots of paperwork, tech needs updating (e.g., electronic signatures)

job_title: Community Wellness Specialist in Covina, CA
pros:
Good training
Competitive salaries
Caring supervisors 
Fulfilling work
Provides great care for clients
Flexible work
cons:
Paperwork heavy (DMH)
Limited locations (Pasadena area, new Covina office)

pros: Build great friendships with coworkers and connections with youth
cons: Not much movement within company. Youth have no consequences for actions.

pros: awesome service, leadership. truly enjoyed the work i did.
cons: try to get more people

pros: Very supportive management and staff.  Flexible hours. Great benefits
cons: high burn out and compassion fatigue

pros: Generous PTO and flexibility.
cons: Lack of growth for some employees

pros:
Experience
Working with families was great
cons: There were a lot of downsides

pros: Supportive staff, flexible, and fair
cons: Low pay, challenging population

pros: Good coworkers and staff that care about the families they serve.
cons: no balanced work-life, Manager micromanage staff regularly. Inconsistency, low morale, people come and go, high turn around.

pros: Pays for phone and mileage.
cons: It's nightmare.  The supervisor is completely unprofessional and bullies staff.

pros: Dedicated coworkers who care about the clients
cons: Super inflated egos of incompetent management
